I envision this site being a source of news and entertainment stories for those participating in air sports. Competition stories, world records, national events, and any story related to air sports on a USA national level is welcome. Please see keywords for particular air sports.

I will always accept stories about competitions and world records. Keep in mind these stories should be after the competition or record is complete.

FYI, so I don't waste your time, I do reject stories for being in one of the 'Quick and Dirty Rejects' below.

The Quick and Dirty Rejects:
1) No local flying club articles. Subject matter should be pointed to national level or international level. 

2) No grandma goes hang gliding, skydiving, etc. 

3) No articles where pilot dies or injured.

4) No articles where local reporter goes hang gliding, skydiving, etc.

5) No articles about 'what is hang gliding?', 'what is paramotoring?', etc. 

6) Due to my limited number of articles purchased, I can only accept competition write-ups after the competition is complete. No preview stories of upcoming competitions please. 

7) No biographicals unless included as part of a story about one of the pilots in a competition. There should be more emphasis on the competition than the pilots bio. 

8) No combined competition articles. If there are 3 competition active, I prefer an article for each competition rather one article for all three. 

Page Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/AirSportsNet

Borrower Persona Information

========================

Identifying the Borrower Persona (#1)

1. What is the typical career title of your borrower? Real Estate Investor

2. What skills does your ideal borrower have? Experienced with property rehabbing and management.

3. How many years has your borrower been involved in their trade? Are they considered a professional? 

If they have acquired, rehabbed, and managed at least 5 to 10 properties over the past several years they are 

considered to be experienced.

1. Is your ideal borrower married? Does he/she have kids? Are they wealthy? What are their goals?

 The ideal borrower would be married with kids, over 40, with a net worth of over $1,000,000.

2. What are some of the hobbies your ideal borrower partake in? What do they enjoy? What do they care 

about? They are conservative, enjoy financial stability, and are aggressive with making things happen.

3. What type of personality do they possess? Confident? Smart? Eccentric? They are typically smart, 

technically savvy, risk takers, which are not afraid to take charge.

1. Does your ideal borrower use or need your product or service? Some prefer and are able to pay all 

cash, others either need to borrow money or prefer to leverage borrowed money.

2. How will your ideal borrower benefit from your product or service? They will benefit by borrowing at a 

rate of 10% to 12% and obtaining a return on their investment of 18% to 30%+.

3. Will your ideal borrower be able to differentiate you from your competitors? Yes. Rate, price, and 

4. What questions would you ask your ideal borrower if he/she were here right now? What experience do 

you have at flipping real estate? How are you going to make the payments and what is your exit strategy?

5. Which features from your business will appeal to your ideal borrower the most? Will it help them 

resolve an issue or problem? Yes. We provide them with loans they cannot get at banks and we process the 

loan request much faster.

We publish a monthly newsletter for real estate agents to send to their clients. Almost all of our readers are homeowners. Our general content is seasonal so it is always changing. We prefer the content to be a quick read, conversational, light and friendly in tone and interesting. Clever and fun is good.

The newsletter publisher believes that his readers will only spend  a maximum of 2 minutes on the inside spread. This means the articles need to be skimmable with interesting headlines, subheads to break up the copy, bullets and very short chunks of copy.

This is a printed newsletter. Please do not rely on links unless asked to do so. All articles should stand on their own with NO REFERENCE to the real estate agents. 

Page size is 8.5 x 11 so please write copy length accordingly. 
Full page = 400 words

Write with subheads and possibly bullets to make the articles skimable. 

ALL ARTICLES MUST INCLUDE A SUMMARY SENTENCE FOR THE TABLE OF CONTENTS. This sentence in addition to the word count.

The goal of the articles is to provide as much factual information as possible to the reader about the topic. If the article is about a DIY project, include where the pieces and parts can be purchased. If the article is about party planning, we need to say specifically where to get the items mentioned. As in all journalism, please keep in mind WHO, WHAT, WHERE, WHEN and HOW.

This is a national publication so don't be specific to any city state or region.

PLEASE DO NOT LINK BACK TO OUR WEBSITE. Our readers cannot link from a printed newsletter and it is annoying to deal with in layout.

Here is a link to nine past issues so you can see the type of copy we prefer:
https://flic.kr/p/nkQQdd

Please keep in mind that these articles were written when this publication was local.

Please include things about interviewing health care professionals, biometrics, wearables (like google glasses that can be used for eye tracking), research gaming or gamification, or facial coding or consumer insights, I think these categories might be helpful.

Avoid grammar contractions and use their full text, ie. instead of don't and isn't please use do not and is not.  When saying 'contact us', please use the business name instead of 'us'.  Capitalize all words in titles except a, an, the, at, by, for, in, of, on, to, up, and, as, but, it, or, and nor.

Glenvale Villas is a private aged care community that provides supported living. Customer segment is those requiring some level of care. NOT a retirement home.

Key differences to traditional nursing homes.
See http://www.glenvalevillas.com.au/no-to-nursing-homes
 for more info:

The care of an aged care facility, with the independence of a retirement village.
Residents buy in and own their own home. Traditional nursing home system in Australia uses a bond system - you never own your home. 
Homes are fully self contained with kitchen, lounge, bedroom, laundry and balcony. Traditional nursing homes give you one room with a bed and bathroom.
Homes are 3 times the size of nursing home rooms.
Residents have full independence to come and go as they like.
Residents have a network of 24/7 nursing care around them, which we call a Continuous Care system
Continuous Care is available from low care right up to high care general nursing, providing true ageing-in-place. When residents' care needs increase they do not need to move out.
Continuous Care can increase to your needs and reduce when you don’t need as much care.
Continuous Care is individualised, so couples with different care needs can stay together. The traditional nursing home system will split them apart.
Residents also have a support network (domestic) that will help with everything from doing the laundry to supplying meals.
Residents can choose to make their own meals in their own homes, eat in the community restaurant, or have meals from the restaurant delivered to their door.
Residents only pay for what they use. Fees increase if care or support increases, but fees also reduce when care and support reduces. 
A Director of Care monitors all residents regularly to provide preventative care.
A Registered Nurse is on staff. 
Residents can alter and decorate their homes as they wish.
Residents can sell their home when they move out.

Main focus of blog:
Fresh content weekly.
Aged care has a negative perception of old style nursing homes, which still exist. Attempting to educate market that we are different. 
Most website visitors are the adult children (50-60 years old) of those needing aged care. They have strong emotions about their parents welfare, and usually stubborn parents.
A visit to the community normally changes people’s perceptions completely, but getting them to visit is difficult.
People are hesitant to move to aged care because they feel their life will be over. Attempting to educate that they still have full independence and their own home.
Crisis is usually the main decision maker, which is often too late. Attempting to educate market to be ‘forward thinkers’

Terms to use:
Community - never use ‘facility’
Older - never use ‘elderly’
Residents - never use ‘patients'
Aged care - never use ‘retirement'
Never use ‘nursing home’ unless referring to the traditional system.

I'm a business coach that helps women design businesses and lives they love. I'm a former corporate consultant that worked for Fortune 150 companies. After I had my son, I quickly determined that the corporate life no longer fit my lifestyle. I want to help other women do the same. For instance, I had a client that came to me as a referral . She was a photographer that wanted a marketing strategy for her business. After one session, she shared that she has rheumatoid arthritis and no longer wanted to shoot weddings or carry around large equipment. Whoa...okay, so let's take a step back. Rather than just moved forward and give her some marketing strategy, I revamped all of her services to meet her new limitations and desires. We got her doing Iphone photography, Instagram takeovers and teaching workshops. Had she gone to someone else, she may experienced some success but she would have fallen out of love with her business and eventually quit thinking it was no longer for her. This is a perfect example of my mission. To design better businesses, and create a better world.

I would like to promote my companywhich is called Genetoo Inc.
Genetoo is a Delaware C-Corp that has licensed a Patent from NASA.

Genetoo is the result of a Startup Competition that its team won. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) is launching “Startup NASA”, a new initiative to encourage the use of federally funded technologies by start-up companies.  “Startup NASA” includes the opportunity for new companies to license NASA technologies with no up-front payment and kicks off an effort with the Center for Advancing Innovation (CAI) to encourage more space technology spin-offs by entrepreneurs. Startup NASA helps address two of the biggest challenges faced by start-up companies: raising capital and securing intellectual property rights. By eliminating up-front licensing fees, NASA is letting new companies hold onto their cash while securing the intellectual property rights needed to secure their competitive market space. This benefit is available to companies formed to commercialize NASA technology.  In addition, to foster the creation of new start-up companies and encourage adoption of NASA technologies, NASA will work with the CAI to run a multi-phase business plan competition in 2016. CAI will review NASA’s portfolio of technologies and identify those that have near-term commercialization potential.  CAI will conduct outreach teams to explore the market potential of the technologies and write business plans.  The winners of the competition will be awarded a cash prize, provided by third-party venture capital investors, and will be encouraged to incorporate and pursue licensing the technologies from NASA, using their winnings as seed funding for the new business.

Hänel Storage Systems manufactures automated storage & retrieval systems such as our signature products, the Rotomat vertical carousel and the Lean-Lift Vertical Lift Module.  These products were developed on the principle that stored items can be brought to the person, rather than the person having to find the items in storage.

Our units provide:
1. Increased floor space - Vertical storage frees existing floor space that can be used to store more inventory or add additional services and production capacity, without the high cost of new construction.  Customers can often reclaim up to 80% of their floor space.
2. Increased inventory accuracy - Hänel's inventory management options can improve inventory accuracy to over 99%, reducing the likelihood of overstocking, parts shortages, expired items and the time spent on correcting errors.
3. Increased productivity - A customer's staff can pick and place more parts in less time, with fewer people, for significant time savings and a boost to their overall productivity.
4. Increased inventory security - All valuable inventory is stored within an enclosed unit, under lock and key for enhanced security.  Further protection by password access, keycard swipe or RFID reader provides further security.
5. Improved ergonomics - Stored items are brought directly to the operator, so our customer's staff no longer has to walk along rows of shelving, climbing or stooping to find items, or carry heavy or bulky items up and down ladders.

Our units store everything from paper records to small parts to large items...Items ranging from nuts and bolts to entire engine blocks.

The name "Hänel" has stood for innovative solutions and quality since the 1950s.  Our storage solutions are custom-manufactured for every customer, so they are sure to meet the needs of the application.  We have provided storage solutions for manufacturing, tooling, automotive, healthcare, pharmacy, government, warehousing & distribution, aviation & aerospace, construction, engineering, electronics, pharmaceuticals, toys and many other industries.

Hänel Storage Systems is the North American sales office of Hänel in Germany.  Other sales offices are located in France and Netherlands, and we have distribution centers in 60 countries.  Our units are manufactured in Germany and Switzerland.

CENTRL is the first shared platform for companies to exchange critical business information. Businesses today have a variety of partners - clients, investors, vendors, distributors - with whom they exchange information like contracts, reports, metrics, risk assessments, etc. Today primarily done using excel, word, email or portals which does not provide a single repository of granular partner related information and results in loss of efficiency.
CENTRL is the first platform that allows companies to request, publish and share this information. It provides both  parties equally powerful application with full-blown capabilities, making the process efficient and agile. Also core to CENTRL’s platform are the collaboration features.Intra-company & inter-company collaboration is available at the most granular levels within the application.This eliminates the need to go out-of-band and the context is never lost emails.

There are 2 modules in CENTRL that can be packaged into 3 different products. The modules are:
1) Documents: Allows companies to request or publish documents to/from partners. This includes documents like metrics, financial reports, policy documents, security and compliance documents etc.
2) Questionnaires: Allows companies to conduct variety of assessments, conduct due diligence and gather relevant information from partners or third parties.. This includes information security assessments, financial due diligence, onsite audits, vendor risk assessments etc.

*Please no off-site hyperlinks, only on-site!

We are a new password management solution that believes the tools you use to keep your digital identify safe should be just as delightful as any other app or product you use. We believe everyone should have a password manager to help keep their information safe, but that it should be fun and easy to use but most importantly leave you free to roam the internet without worrying about remembering your passwords or the security of sites you give your information to.

Our password manager takes away even the need to remember your master password by assigning you a random, secure master password and then encoding that password in a set of images we train you to remember. The image training using double encoding theory to help you learn, prompting you to read a quirky fact about something found in the image and search for and click on something else in the image. This process makes your master password as secure as a truly random password but as memorable as your mother's maiden name.

About Zenlayer

Zenlayer’s global connection platform enables enterprises to quickly deploy and manage IT resources worldwide so they can deliver superior user experience.  We offer on-demand bare metal cloud, SD-WAN (software defined wide area networking), edge computing, and colocation in more than 70 data centers worldwide.

Zenlayer is headquartered in Los Angeles and Shanghai, with offices in Hong Kong, Singapore, Beijing and Shenzhen.


Our Vision and Content Strategy

The purpose of our blog is to generate brand awareness and sales leads.  To do this, we try to make our blog:
•	Informative
•	Interesting
•	Relevant to our products and services

Sample topics may include industry trends, explanations of technical concepts, application of technologies to real life use cases, etc.

Our target audience: 
Enterprises (or rather, the people that work at the companies) that want to expand digitally into other regions of the world, for example:
•	Video streaming service in the U.S. that wants to improve its user experience (decrease latency, improve video quality) in Brazil
•	Mobile gaming company in Russia that wants to make sure its Indonesian users do not experience lag when playing its games

Our differentiation:
•	Global coverage: six continents, 25+ countries (including countries that are traditionally difficult to get into, such as China, India, Russia, Brazil, Indonesia, South Africa, etc.), 70+ data centers
•	On-demand SD-WAN: dedicated (private) networks that allow enterprises to bypass congestion on the public Internet that can be provisioned on-demand with a pay-as-you-go payment model
•	Service: rapid deployment (multiple sites at the same time), quick responses (support response time < 30 minutes), 24/7 English and Chinese technical support

 
Tone/Style details for our blog:
•	Conversational tone
•	Post must help readers accomplish something, and/or learn from examples.
•	Detailed explanations of our industry
•	Short, concise paragraphs that are easy to read
•	Fully formatted sections to make posts easy to skim through

The site offers visitors in-depth information about the company’s popular baked goods, rich visuals and information about catering services as well as national and local delivery.

“As our business has grown, we have had a lot of interest in our cupcakes in a jar from all over the United States,” said a spokesperson for the company. “Now, you can order cupcakes in a jar from anywhere.”

Sunflour Baking Company’s Cupcake in a Jar is fast becoming a hit with customers — so much so that orders are pouring in from as far away as Alaska and Hawaii. The Cupcake in a Jar features two cupcakes, including icing, in a reusable, recyclable mason jar. Flavors include Black and White, Blondie, Caramel, Carrot Cake, Chocolate Caramel and Classic Birthday. A host of other recipes are available, such as Key Lime, Chocolate Peanut Butter and German Chocolate. They are available in packs of two, four or six. They last for two weeks in the refrigerator and up to six months in the freezer. They are made from scratch and hand-packed.

Sunflour Baking Company has been serving Charlotte from its original Elizabeth location since 2009. The Dilworth location opened in 2016; the Harrisburg location opened just recently. Owned and operated by the Parrish family since 2014, Sunflour enjoys a love of baking, a passion for excellent service and a keen interest in contributing to the local community. They serve organic coffee and a variety of pastries, with local delivery available in the Charlotte area.

We are a technology company that provides software to corporations to help them organize their charitable giving and empower their employees to raise money for causes they are passionate about. Key highlights of our platform: 
-Allow employees to have access to Giving accounts
- Employers can add funds to the employee Givinga accounts and the employee can direct the funds to the 501(c)3 of their choice
-Employees can add money to their account through payroll deductions and receive a full tax write-off
-Employees can run crowdfunding campaigns to collect donations from external donors and amplify the amount given to their selected 501(c)3
-External donors to a campaign also get a tax write-off
- Employers are provided with full reporting that gives insight into how giving is taking place (how much money sent, which charities, etc.) 
- The platform allows for matching campaigns to be easily run and managed by the employers.

Key Themes For Corporations:
The Givinga platform combines financial tools w/ unique giving vehicles to: 1)  Create a new benefits & monetize giving 2) Empower workforce 3) Convert employees into Ambassadors 4) Reduce costs 5) Amplify Corporate Impact, all w/out increasing existing budget

Our target audience is C-level executives who already contribute to charity and encourage their employees to do the same but want to maximize their donations, streamline giving, get better ROI in the form of happy, loyal employees, etc.

IDEA1 is an apartment building located in the East Village near downtown San Diego. It’s a unique community that invites entrepreneurs, visionaries, and inspired professionals to live, work, and socialize. The average age of the primary market is upper 30’s, however, will span upper-twenty-somethings to mid 50’s and 60s. It has 295 apartments, commercial space, and collaborative workspaces. 

This is a new property that doesn’t have residents yet. It’s important to keep this in mind and not refer to residents directly. Lease up began in early August. Move-in dates are not confirmed yet.

We would like blog content that appeals to the residents who live in this community. Topics should be community focused and include local events, businesses, restaurants, monthly events,e tc.

The goal of the blog post is to highlight things to do or neighborhood hotspots in the area as an indirect way of showcasing the apartment community itself. Guidelines are as follows:

-Hyper-local: We would like all businesses to be found in the East Village neighborhood of San Diego. Neighboring areas in downtown (for example, Gaslamp Quarter) are also OK to write about if relevant to the property demographic.
-Local businesses/hotspots tailored for resident: Focus on new or interesting restaurants, bars, art galleries, unique stores, pop-ups, etc. in the East Village area.
-Link the apartment website: Link the provided apartment website to a relevant word/phrase. Be sure to include a mention/link to the apartments and end the post with a call-to-action statement (ie: contact us today to learn more!).

Things to avoid:
-Gyms and bike shops as the property already has these things
-Fast food restaurants//chain restaurants 
-Businesses/things that are not in East Village, San Diego
-Holiday or religious content
-If writing about a restaurant - do not just list out menu items and their ingredients. Go into more detail the atmosphere, fun facts about the restaurant etc.
-If writing about a business - do not just list services. Include fun facts, atmosphere, etc.
-Do not use the words “tenant” and “complex”. Instead use "resident" or "community"

WHAT WE DO: In short it is an an end to end platform, from measuring where to spend down to a zip code level, programmatically creating the ads, buying through multiple channels and adjusting based off outcomes and revenue in your marketplace.

Because tamme integrates all the way from your analytics through to the impressions that users see tamme's able to gain a holistic picture of your marketplace.

All success measures are brought back to both moving users through funnel stages and final/repeat goal conversions, such as ordering a meal, booking a car or hiring a staff member.

Then all expenditure is measured back to simple unit economics:

i. ACV
ii. CAC
iii. CTS
iv. Churn rate
v. MRR
vi. CLV

This allows all marketing activities that tamme undertakes to be tied directly back to the core function of the business instead of being measured by vanity marketing metrics.

Background:
We provide accounting and financial strategy services to small and medium businesses specifically in the marketing and tech industries. We differ from traditional accounting firms in that we are proactive instead of reactive. We use a company's finances to tell a story and shape a pathway for future growth of the company. By focusing in a couple key industries, we are highly specialized in our clients' verticals and can use our experience in the industry to guide our clients through the opportunities and pitfalls that are typically seen. 
Purpose of blog:
Internally:
We seek to improve SEO, draw readers into inquiring about Richtr's services, and establish thought leadership in the financial and business strategy sphere for marketing and tech firms. 
Externally:
Inform our audience on how to be able to focus on their strengths and the core operations of their companies. We seek to give advice on how to free up C-level leadership's time in order for them to grow the company. Our focus is on charting a path to growth for our clients and the information/guidance we provide helps them do so. With an emphasis on providing financial and strategy advice for marketers, creatives, and tech entrepreneurs that will guide them to success.

Our audience consists of entrepreneurs, marketers, creatives, and technologists who lead their own companies.

We are not your granddaddy's accounting firm! Should be written from our perspective as Richtr Financial Studio. Our language should appeal to our target audience as much as possible.

Financial guidance

Brand voice: 
- No ambiguous statements
- Don't list any benefits without also disclosing the risks
- Don't say anything similar to 'secure’, ‘guaranteed, ‘protected’ 
- No recommending/suggesting an investment strategy/advice/service/product

- Stating investment-related facts and figures without evaluating them
- Explaining how acting differently will cause different results, without favouring either of the results

- Personal (voice: accessible & helpful)

Style: 
- Simplicity: short words/sentences to make a point; avoid jargon/acronyms

- Active voice: include useful information such as relevant data and dates 
- Embed examples
- No content duplication
- Add outgoing links

Ideation: 
Here’s a list of some of the possible angles to kickstart ideation: 
- List best articles published on the subject in a certain period 
- Compile a checklist that is easy to download and print 
- List the best tools for doing something related to the article topic
- Stimulate a discussion. Write a “What will happen if...” article
- Every article can be turned into a list and readers love lists 
- Put together a quiz and tailor it to a certain audience 
- Explain results of a recent study on the subject 
- Summarise something and draw a conclusion 
- Turn existing data into a small case study 
- Respond to media mentions or criticism 
- Put together a “for dummies” article 
- Gather predictions and forecasts

The Client:

Client Name: Harbour Rock	
Client Website: www.Harbour-Rock.com

About the Client:

Client Industry: Harbour Rock is an outsourced CFO firm and management advisory/consulting services. 

Company Information & Overview:  Harbour Rock offers a distinct alternative to establishing a full-time financial back office – you get responsive, efficient, and proactive financial management advisory or outsourced CFO services on an as-needed basis. We invest the time to understand your business so we can present innovative solutions that help you achieve your goals.

Target Persona of the Blogs: Board of Directors,  CEO, CIO, COO, CDO, CCO, VCs, HR professionals, CPAs

Target Audience of the Blogs: Blog readers are likely very established managers at the least, but most are C-level executives – predominately male – and in their 40s – 60s typically. They either lost their CFO due to quitting or firing, are being audited and need help, their accountant or bookkeeper is overwhelmed, their current financial team is struggling with reporting, they’re looking to expand their business geographically (overseas especially) or are a start-up and are looking for someone to step into the role. They’re very well educated, and are looking for insight – not to be sold. 

Tone of the Writing Style : The client is very relatable, friendly, and witty, but professional and intelligent. Spare writing that is full of jargon and filled with overwhelming words – we’re looking for content that is meaty, understandable, and easily digestible. Making a move to an outsourced CFO is a big move for any company, and is a relatively new idea- so we want prospects and business professionals to be comfortable and not feel overwhelmed. We want to earn trust and build a relationship at each turn of the road, and blogging is a big piece of this puzzle.

Objective of the Blog: We want prospects to be informed and educated. We do not want to sell, but rather be a resource to business and finance – and be a pillar for best practices, honesty, and insight.

Topics/Words to Avoid: We want to avoid politics, digging into conversation about the economy, snarkiness, sarcasm, and humor.  We also do not want to portray fear in the writing, especially as it relates to the fate of a company who is struggling or regarding the economy as a whole.

Topics/Words to Focus On: Our main keywords are management consulting services, outsourced CFOs, part-time CFOs, virtual CFOs, and fractional CFOs.


Published Blogs of Ideal Content/Format: 

•	http://www.harbour-rock.com/blog/is-my-business-ready-for-an-outsourced-cfo
•	http://www.harbour-rock.com/blog/whats-a-kpi-and-why-do-i-care
•	http://www.harbour-rock.com/blog/what-is-an-outsourced-cfos-role-in-the-businesss-lifecycle

Buying real estate in Miami is an excellent investment opportunity for many compelling reasons.

Trends do not look favorable, in the short term, for the Italian real estate market. Which is why many Italians are looking for similar investment opportunities abroad, especially in an economically stable country such as the United States.

Some of the reasons to invest in Miami are:

    Location and climate.
    Being an international tourist attraction and a refuge from colder climates results in high demand for second homes.
    Immigration from South America translates into high demand for first homes.
    Strong commercial appeal: Miami is a large US financial center (after NY) and is home to many companies that use it as a springboard to South America and the Caribbean. It is also an important commercial port and aviation hub for Central and South America.
    Favorable Euro to Dollar exchange rate.
    Highly profitable residential real estate market.
    Purchasing real estate in the South Florida market is affordable and the process is simple.
    Market trends continue to indicate growth in the near term.
    Low investment risk as another economic crisis in this region of the magnitude experienced in 2008 in very unlikely.
    Diverse investment opportunities for properties of all types and intended use (condominiums, detached houses, plots of land to be developed, whole residential and commercial buildings).
    Highly active market.
    Financing is easily available given the stability of the market.

The Miami real-estate market is growing and very active.

The average prices Increased by 16.1% to $ 244,000, the highest point since 2008. The average price per sqf Exceed $ 305 for the first time in five years. The days That a property remains on the market collapsed to 58, the lowest level since 2008.

In the first quarter of 2014 there was the highest number of sales over the past eight years as the inventory of apartments begins to increase to to. The number of sales in the first quarter rose by 3.9% (5,133) over the same quarter last year and Represents the highest number of sales for the first quarter of the last eight years. The inventory of homes for sale grew by 13.2% (12,664) Compared to a year ago, as rising prices Caused the INCREASE in homes for sale on the market.

The normal sales market share Reached the highest rate of the last four years, ie 69.4%. The volume of short sale and foreclosure continues to fall.

In Particular, sales of apartments in the apartment block were up 2% Compared to the same period last year and the number of apartments for sale has Increased even faster (8,846 apartments for sale), factored That has Caused a decline in the rate of market absorption.

In detached houses Increased by 7.1% in the number of sales and 12.2% in the number of homes for sale.

In Particular in South Beach, the average price of the apartments sales grew by 19.6% ($ 355,000).


Most property is easily rented at market price, with some exceptions depending on the building category.

Skyscrapers and large buildings in South Beach, Miami Beach, Downtown, Brickell, Bal Harbor, Aventura and Sunny Isles with luxurious facilities (pool, gym, valet parking, security, lobby, etc.)

    Benefits: Professional tenants with stable incomes and credentials.
    Disadvantages: High condo fees (with rare exceptions)
    Investment target: From $ 250.000- $ 300,000.
    Potential return: 6-7% before management fees and property tax (3-4% net).

Art Deco buildings in South Beach: low-rise buildings, built in the ’20s,’ 30s and ’40s, that have recently been completely renovated.

    Benefits: Long-term rentals (one year) and low condo fees, higher investment yield.
    Disadvantages: Tenant rating slightly lower.
    Investment target: From $ 200,000.
    Potential return: 6-7% before management fees and property tax (4-5% net).

Shop for appreciation: favorable contingency determined by the INCREASE in property prices in the Miami area and the recent, albeit slow, recovery of available financing by banks. The loan to value (financing on the price of purchase) is determined by the building and property being purchased. Financing for foreigners can usually cover up to 60% of the purchase price.

Luxury buildings (from $ 1,5mil): is a more conservative type of investment. Such investments can be made in skyscrapers and large buildings in established areas such as South Beach, Coral Gables, Aventura, Brickell, or in the purchase of entire buildings and Art Deco villas.

Buying Pre-construction: These long-term investments are plentiful. There are over 40+ new skyscrapers under construction in the Miami area.

    Benefits: 10% payment upon booking and by a further 20% in installments, balance the deed; two potential high profitability to the constant growth of the market
    Disadvantages: Sorting and screening of new projects is key. Risks associated with the builder and the long term market must be thoroughly evaluated. Usually condo conversions of Art Deco buildings involve almost no risk because the demand is so high that these units are normally sold out “on paper”.

BUSINESS INFO ON QUICKALYTICS AND ABOUT MY BLOG ENTRY REQUESTS

ABOUT MY BUSINESS
My business is a single product business - web application (software program hosted on the web vs a desktop) called Quickalytics®.  Quickalytics is a HR Performance Management suite of tools offered on an an annual subscription basis (SAAS biz model). The business handles updating Quickalytics by rolling out new features on a bi-weekly basis, selling Quickalytics, and working hard to support our clients. 

WHO I SELL TO

I mostly sell to the executives of professional service firms, and more specifically to CPA (accounting) firms with 50 - 500 employees located in the United States. The firms often have different practices within them, but usually break into Audit, Tax, and sometimes Consulting practices with minimal support staff.  

Most employees are CPAs (or on their way to CPA licensure) with a very small percentage of employees in support functions (IT, Marketing, HR, Clerical).  In firms of 50, many of these support functions are taken on by practicing accountants in a dual role or outsourced completely.

The decision makers for a purchase of a subscription such as Quickalytics are the executives in consultation with the HR people (or people in those roles as they will most likely be the firm’s administrator of Quickalytics and responsible for it’s implementation in the firm.  

The larger of these firms are mostly managed by a Partner/Shareholder who is elected by the other partners to serve as a Firm Manager on a rotating basis.  Smaller firms, are usually run by the firm's founder, the owner and will make this decision in consultation with a partner or two.

This group of posts will be focused on educating on how a pain point can be specifically addressed with an initiative, or other solution type. ABOUT MY BLOG AUDIENCE


The intended audience will be CPA firm managers or other executives along with some HR people.  A very large part of the Quickalytics branding is that we get things done effectively and transparently.  Therefore, the way the blog entries are written needs to reflect that attitude. Here's how I picture it.

When you write this, picture the CEO of a company reading these.  They are coming to this with a purpose in mind - not really a browse mentality.  If they like what they see they will forward info to someone else to follow up (more on that later). To make it easy for them to skim the content they will want, I think most posts should have:
- an executive summary (for a 600-900 words blog post, seriously? Yep!)
- clear supporting topic headings
- bullet points within the text of the body text
- some RELEVANT stats they can relate to
- a clear summary

They are reading for 2 purposes:

1)  Does the value proposition make sense? As an example  - Is frequent feedback something I want for my firm? What would I expect the outcome to be for the firm? Is that worth it? Will the time/money invested in implementing a frequent feedback initiative (for instance) make sense?

2) Does Quickalytics (the firm and the software look like it can deliver? If the blog post is written authoritatively and tracks with their reality, then they will think so.  If I get them to the demo, I can prove it. My goal is to get them to know it will be worth the time to get someone to give them a call to set up a demo.



BLOG STYLE GUIDE

TITLES:  I will ‘seed’ with a title to explain what I am looking for, but I would love it if you would also suggest a few (better) titles to go with your blog post.  

TONE/VOICE:
Executive conversational.  Imagine the tone and voice when CPA firm presidents are talking to each other. 

OVERALL BLOG STYLE
I expect my audience to read in this way: 
They will read the title.
Next, they will read the executive summary (at the top)
Next they will skim through the H2, H3, H4 headings
Next, they will read the summary
Finally, they will read all the way through the blog post. 

Title →  Executive Summary → skim by Reading Headlines/Topic headings→ Summary → Read through blog → CTA.  

Please confirm the readability of the blog post when you are done, to make sure that it’ll make sense and be pleasant to read this way to the reader at each step. They should feel a progression.  The takeaway is that they should get the biggest takeaway as soon as possible.

HEADINGS
Please take advantage of the 3 additional heading sizes (after the title). Title = H1, and then use H2, H3 and H4 headings.  
Please label which header level you are intending for each heading by putting H2, H3, or H4 prior to each heading. (example: H2: USING QUICKALYTICS )

SECTION LENGTHS
Article Titles: <9 words
Executive summary: ~ 5 sentences
Headlines/Topic headings: Max 10 words
(Ending) Summary: 50-150 words (not including our CTA info)
Blog Body: In general keep paragraphs from 1 to 5 sentences

BLOG POST STRUCTURES FOR VARIOUS TYPES

Topic: <insert background explanatory post topic here>

Description:
Title (hook: compellingly connect topic to audience)
Intro (executive summary)
Body 
Intro to topic (definition of ‘initiative’) 
Background of the initiative.  How and when have these initiatives been used? How are they being used now? What kinds of issues does it address and what do the solutions look like? 
If implemented, what should the initiative sponsors expect to see in a successful implementation of this initiative (in general terms). Outcomes.
Provide some examples of what goes into implementing this kind of implementation? Who’s involved, what are the roles, how do things progress, how can you tell if things are going well (or not)? What things should you make sure are in place to maximize the odds of success?
Summary 
However you do it, give the reader the ability to only read this summary and have a really good idea of what the initiative is all about (without having to read anything else).  
CTAs (We will add these later; a Contact us link, and a Further Reading set of links focused on Product How Tos)

BUSINESS INFO ON QUICKALYTICS AND ABOUT MY BLOG ENTRY REQUESTS

ABOUT MY BUSINESS
My business is a single product business - web application (software program hosted on the web vs a desktop) called Quickalytics®.  Quickalytics is a HR Performance Management suite of tools offered on an an annual subscription basis (SAAS biz model). The business handles updating Quickalytics by rolling out new features on a bi-weekly basis, selling Quickalytics, and working hard to support our clients. 

WHO I SELL TO

I mostly sell to the executives of professional service firms, and more specifically to CPA (accounting) firms with 50 - 500 employees located in the United States. The firms often have different practices within them, but usually break into Audit, Tax, and sometimes Consulting practices with minimal support staff.  

Most employees are CPAs (or on their way to CPA licensure) with a very small percentage of employees in support functions (IT, Marketing, HR, Clerical).  In firms of 50, many of these support functions are taken on by practicing accountants in a dual role or outsourced completely.

The decision makers for a purchase of a subscription such as Quickalytics are the executives in consultation with the HR people (or people in those roles as they will most likely be the firm’s administrator of Quickalytics and responsible for it’s implementation in the firm.  

The larger of these firms are mostly managed by a Partner/Shareholder who is elected by the other partners to serve as a Firm Manager on a rotating basis.  Smaller firms, are usually run by the firm's founder, the owner and will make this decision in consultation with a partner or two.

BUSINESS INFO ON QUICKALYTICS AND ABOUT MY BLOG ENTRY REQUESTS

ABOUT MY BUSINESS
My business is a single product business - web application (software program hosted on the web vs a desktop) called Quickalytics®.  Quickalytics is a HR Performance Management suite of tools offered on an an annual subscription basis (SAAS biz model). The business handles updating Quickalytics by rolling out new features on a bi-weekly basis, selling Quickalytics, and working hard to support our clients. 

WHO I SELL TO

I mostly sell to the executives of professional service firms, and more specifically to CPA (accounting) firms with 50 - 500 employees located in the United States. The firms often have different practices within them, but usually break into Audit, Tax, and sometimes Consulting practices with minimal support staff.  

Most employees are CPAs (or on their way to CPA licensure) with a very small percentage of employees in support functions (IT, Marketing, HR, Clerical).  In firms of 50, many of these support functions are taken on by practicing accountants in a dual role or outsourced completely.

The decision makers for a purchase of a subscription such as Quickalytics are the executives in consultation with the HR people (or people in those roles as they will most likely be the firm’s administrator of Quickalytics and responsible for it’s implementation in the firm.  

The larger of these firms are mostly managed by a Partner/Shareholder who is elected by the other partners to serve as a Firm Manager on a rotating basis.  Smaller firms, are usually run by the firm's founder, the owner and will make this decision in consultation with a partner or two.


MY THREE TYPES OF BLOG ENTRY REQUESTS

These blog entries (which will be placed on my website, and referenced in our newsletter):  
Provide these decision makers with a focused, relevant explanation of specific initiatives and other solutions to their firm’s needs.  
Provide these decision makers with focused, relevant info about a specific selection of solutions to issues their firms face; 
Provide these same decision makers (and maybe some support people) focused, relevant info on the how Quickalytics can put implementing these solutions within practical reach of their firm.

Initiative Background Explanatory Posts
 This group of posts will provide a background explanatory on initiatives so that if a firm wants to implement an initiative, they can get a quick, but well done sense of that what that initiative is, what it entails, and what it is used for.  Decision makers are busy either rainmaking for their firm, or managing it - often both.  When they don’t have the specific background on some of these things, these ‘explanatories’ will fill that gap.  

Examples:
Employee Engagement programs
What is Frequent Feedback?
Why implement an initiative to Identify Top and Emerging Talent?

Calls to Actions we will place at the end of the post:
Contact us link, 
To a post on how to specifically implement that initiative (see purpose 3 types below) with Quickalytics and
Possibly to a post doing a deeper dive on exactly how that initiative addresses certain issues (see Purpose 2 below).

From Pain Points to Solutions Posts
This group of posts will be focused on educating on how a pain point can be specifically addressed with an initiative, or other solution type.  Unlike the Purpose 1 posts (above) which explain WHAT an initiative is, these posts will explain HOW implementing an initiative like this will address specific pain points.  They will discuss challenges to implementing, how these challenges are met, and what kinds of benefits to expect. 

Examples: 
Addressing Retention issues through employee engagement
Turning around a disengaged workforce leveraging frequent feedback
How ensuring alignment, leads to engaged employees
What if your top employees informally recommended your firm as preferred place to work? 
Ensure the right people are recognized and rewarded
Tired of watching fast trackers jump ship?  


At the end of the post, readers should want to contact us for a demo of our software, or feel compelled to explore more detail on the initiatives discussed.  Therefore, we will place the following CTAs at the end of these posts:
A Contact us link, 
Link to the Initiative implementation overview type post (see below), 
Link to Initiative background explanatory post to concertize their understanding of the initiative.

Initiative Implementation Overviews

These blog posts are for those that have decided they want to implement an initiative in their firm (because, what we wrote about addressing the pain points was compelling?)  So, they are coming here to understand what specifically is involved in actually implementing this initiative or program for their firm.  These are the posts where I will connect their solution to the qualities that make my product a good fit.  But, these will still be overviews, not product fact sheets. Instead, these will cover what needs to be done to successfully implement the initiative and what qualities are needed to make those implementations practical for a CPA firm to implement.  Lucky for me - Quickalytics has those specific qualities. :) 

Examples of various types of programs:
- Continuous Performance Improvement programs
- Frequent feedback programs
- Engagement programs
- Talent Management programs
- Retention programs
- Coaching and Mentoring programs
- Alignment Programs
- Goal Programs
- Management Effectiveness programs
- Reward and Recognition programs
- Etc

Various ways of making it practical (I'll provide specifics per topic):
- Focus the task to what's essential
- Work within the firm's workflows.  
- Drastically cut or eliminate administrative tasks from what people are doing.
- Eliminate the need for any training
- Make it easy to leverage the results 6 ways from Sunday
- Allow the customization options to make the CPA firm 'fit' perfect

At the end of the post, readers should want to contact us for a demo of our software.  If not, they will want to view the Quick Start Implementation Guide for implementating this initiative. On the other hand, if they still don’t feel compelled, we will provide links back to the other 2 types of posts, or a request to sign up for our newsletter.   Therefore, we will place the following CTAs at the end of these posts:
A Contact us link
A link to a 2 page Quick Start Guide for implementing this initiative in Quickalytics.  
Links to relevant further reading to the other blog posts
A link to sign up for the newsletter. 
to the Initiative implementation overview type post (see below), 
Link to Initiative background



ABOUT MY BLOG AUDIENCE


The intended audience will be CPA firm managers or other executives along with some HR people.  A very large part of the Quickalytics branding is that we get things done effectively and transparently.  Therefore, the way the blog entries are written needs to reflect that attitude. Here's how I picture it.

When you write this, picture the CEO of a company reading these.  They are coming to this with a purpose in mind - not really a browse mentality.  If they like what they see they will forward info to someone else to follow up (more on that later). To make it easy for them to skim the content they will want, I think most posts should have:
- an executive summary (for a 600-900 words blog post, seriously? Yep!)
- clear supporting topic headings
- bullet points within the text of the body text
- some RELEVANT stats they can relate to
- a clear summary

They are reading for 2 purposes:

1)  Does the value proposition make sense? As an example  - Is frequent feedback something I want for my firm? What would I expect the outcome to be for the firm? Is that worth it? Will the time/money invested in implementing a frequent feedback initiative (for instance) make sense?

2) Does Quickalytics (the firm and the software look like it can deliver? If the blog post is written authoritatively and tracks with their reality, then they will think so.  If I get them to the demo, I can prove it. My goal is to get them to know it will be worth the time to get someone to give them a call to set up a demo.



BLOG STYLE GUIDE

TITLES:  I will ‘seed’ with a title to explain what I am looking for, but I would love it if you would also suggest a few (better) titles to go with your blog post.  

TONE/VOICE:
Executive conversational.  Imagine the tone and voice when CPA firm presidents are talking to each other. 

OVERALL BLOG STYLE
I expect my audience to read in this way: 
They will read the title.
Next, they will read the executive summary (at the top)
Next they will skim through the H2, H3, H4 headings
Next, they will read the summary
Finally, they will read all the way through the blog post. 

Title →  Executive Summary → skim by Reading Headlines/Topic headings→ Summary → Read through blog → CTA.  

Please confirm the readability of the blog post when you are done, to make sure that it’ll make sense and be pleasant to read this way to the reader at each step. They should feel a progression.  The takeaway is that they should get the biggest takeaway as soon as possible.

Art N' Glow creates glow in the dark paints and powders locally in Texas.

Our Products

There is something magical about phosphorescent materials and while the initial concept was to bring glow in the dark to canvas and other fine art, we quickly ended up with an assortment of unique, quality pieces of glow in the dark art from around the world. From our glowing glass to our glowing sand pictures, nearly every one of our products is inspired by art, science, or nature.

In addition to our gallery of amazing art pieces, we also sell glow in the dark paint and pigment so that you can create your own works of art.  Star murals, blown glass, jewelry, resin casting, model painting, and more are all possible uses for our line of paints and powders.

Our Technology

All of our products are made with the newest generation of glow in the dark materials which glow 10 times brighter and much longer than the more common and less expensive zinc sulfide technology.  Also, every one of our glow in the dark powders are encapsulated so that they can be used in either solvent or water base mediums without degrading.

We want our blog to serve as an inspiration to artist on how they can use our products for their future projects. We want to educate them on the different uses of Glow Paint and Glow Powders by giving them ideas on different projects they can do with our products.

We want blog articles that will rank well within google for Glow Paint, Glow Powder, and Glow in the Dark Paints, Glow in Dark Powders. We want articles that not only educate but give specific project ideas they can use with our products.

Our target audience:

Prospect Target

- Industries excluded – lawyers, franchises, realtors
- Industries included/targeted – Dentist, Doctors, Optometrist/Eye Doctor, Home Health Care, Financial Advisors, Insurance Brokers, Plastic Surgeons, Spas, Delivery companies, professional services etc.
- Company Targets – Our prospects mainly target consumers
- Minimum Annual Revenue – 3 million, been in business over 5 years and employ ten or more employees
- Advertising/Marketing Budget – Minimum of $2500 / monthly
•	Decision Makers – Company owners, C-level executives (VP of Marketing, Chief Marketing Officer (CMO), Director of Marketing, etc.)

Target Prospect Situation
Our target prospect is an owner (CEO, Founder) in the situation of: - 
	Having aspirations/dreams of growth - generating more revenue and generating more profitability from their company.
	They fear losing sales, market share and profits to their competitors and hiring the wrong employee or service provider to name a few.
	They are very interested in further growing the company sales and profits while watching costs.

Background info on our app: We're a company born of the disruption in retail that's led to the loss of thousands of jobs. Like the retail industry, the rise of artificial intelligence and robotics is accelerating the job loss in other blue collar segments like light industrial and transportation. Parallel to this disruption, there's a cultural shift where people don't want to work 9-5 one-company-career jobs anymore. Our aim is to get blue collar workers (light industrial, retail, etc) into jobs faster by working with staffing agencies to increase their efficiency using technology.
 
Our platform allows agencies to send messages to workers with the job details the agencies have. This saves them from having to call each worker, share the job requirements and have lengthy conversations with people who may not be qualified/ interested/able to get to the job.

We can send messages via bulk-sms, email or through an app that we white-label for the agency (think whatsapp/messenger but with the agency's logo on it).

We want our blog content to do two things:
1) appeal to the staffing agency recruiters showing them how our platform makes it easier for them to connect with their candidates.
2) appeal to the staffing agency owners showing them that they'll save money/time by using technology to align their agency with the shift to the gig economy.

Target audience: staffing agencies looking to streamline processes. Especially staffing agencies in the light industrial field.

We created an Artificially Intelligent Sales Assistant that is able to hold conversations in English over email. Our customers are using our technology inside their Sales/Marketing Department. There, our conversational semantic email-engine reads and responds to email from leads. 
Example: A website visitor fills out a webform, leaving his email address, and says "I'm interested in your product". Our AI-Assistant picks up that signal (email message), reads it, understands its content and engages the lead with an email response. We deliver powerful business outcomes for 21K+ users across 85+ countries with a fully-featured omnichannel messaging/live chat solution. SnapEngage clients consistently see better sales conversions, higher Customer Satisfaction (CSAT)/NPS and lower cost per interaction after switching to SnapEngage. Our fully-featured solution offers robust CRM & Help Desk integrations, is HIPAA & PCI compliant, is available in 30+ languages and includes advanced analytics to prove ROI.

GENERAL WRITING/EDITORIAL GUIDELINES:
- Our brand voice is human, friendly, smart, and straightforward.
- Our tone needs to blend casual/friendly with business professional
- The focus should be educational and engaging content
- Our blog's mission is to educate, engage, inspire, and guide readers.
- We love actionable content that educates our readers, and insightful content that says something meaningful.
- Each post should reference 3-5 reputable, current sources and/or studies (sources/studies from within the last 3 years if possible). Think reputable technology and business industry blogs, research studies, business and technology news websites (such as Forrester Research, MarTech Advisor, TechCrunch, VentureBeat, Harvard Business Review, The Economist, New York Times, etc). Please do NOT cite sources from blogs of live chat software competitors or other direct competition of SnapEngage.
- Please use active voice (vs. passive voice) whenever possible.
- Use descriptive headers and subheaders to break up content. Bonus points if it's punchy and creative.
- Feel free to use contractions as you see fit.
- We like the Oxford comma ;)
- Strive to create content that covers the topic fully while remaining easy to digest (keep paragraphs fairly short, make use of subheaders to group thoughts, use bulleted lists where appropriate, etc). SnapEngage blog readers are a busy bunch, so grab the reader right away.
- It's ok to use a bit of tasteful humor (remember, we're human!)
- Writing about a person/people? Strive to be respectful, inclusive, and compassionate.
- Please note that we will remove any copy we view as self-promotional.

Who is Netsanity? We are an American company, started by two dads and a mom with school-aged children. Like many other parents, we were exhausted trying to find a way to protect our kids from the dangers of the internet. When we were growing up, the biggest issue our parents faced was to make sure we did not hog the phone too long, or watch too much television! Well, how times have changed! Now, it seems that every home contraption is internet enabled. Kids have phones and tablets that can reach anything and anyone.
After 12 months of testing and programming, along with countless nights of researching and coding, we created something that we believe, does not currently exist - a simple, affordable, and transparent cloud service that can be installed on an Apple device to give a parent control and peace of mind!
Launched in early 2014, our first service, NetSanity Mobile Service for Apple, is based on the popular Apple iOS 7 & 8 platform. With NetSanity Mobile, parents will be able to purchase a device license, install it on their child’s Apple mobile device, and control internet access from their private and secure admin portal. Features like blocking internet apps, content filtering while browsing, scheduling when kids can use the phone – all these and more are included in the initial release of the service.

Not an App! Works in the background and is transparent. Our service is totally different and revolutionary! Your child cannot remove it. Only parents can remove it. You manage everything from the convenient dashboard on our website. There is nothing like it and your first 7 days are free!

Remember – we use the services just as you do. Our kids are protected and they are our best and worst critics!

Dr. David Davtyan is a bariatric surgeon with multiple locations throughout the greater Los Angeles area. Here are some guidelines for writing for him: 
1. Regarding the tone of the writing, he like's an open, inviting and most of all empathetic feel. As a bariatric patient himself, he is able to better understand his patient's struggles. 
2. Whenever writing his name it should always be in full "Dr. David Davtyan" not "Dr. Davtyan".
3. The content should be user-friendly, not too technical, but well researched and in depth. It needs to offer real value to the reader. This industry is very competitive and there is already a ton of content out there, so creating better, more comprehensive content is necessary to stand out from the crowd. 
4. The doctor likes to emphasize a patient's journey and to always put the patient first.
5. He doesn't want to emphasize the negatives, complications, etc. He wants to have a bright, positive, cheery spin on these topics. 
6. Whenever possible he would like to mention the name of his practice, Davtyan Medical Weight Loss And Wellness such as "The team at Davtyan Weight Loss And Wellness will prepare you for your procedure by..."
7. Wherever it makes sense he would like it mentioned that the surgeries are performed at "The Weight Loss Surgery Center of Los Angeles".
8. Please use the target keyword in each subheading (or at least in as many as possible).
9. If writing about a particular procedure, please check our website first to see what we've already said about it and to make sure you are not writing duplicate content. 

Hopefully, that helps!

Our first brand is KZ Gear: kzgear.com

Our client base ranges from college students to young professionals to younger families, rough age bracket of 18-42. We are building a social media community of individuals who are active, enjoy being outdoors, and spending time with friends and family. 

Our major areas of focus on outdoor activity are: 

On the water - we offer a line of floatable sunglasses and accessories to protect valuables from the water (phone cases, even water proof solar chargers). We focus a lot on time on and around the water and activities related to the beach, ocean, lakes, fishing, boating, skiing, etc.

Hiking and climbing - we also promote exploring the world around us while hiking and climbing. Many of our ambassadors are very active using GoPro's, drones, etc to capture beautiful landscapes and their adventures in the mountains, through the deserts, and jumping off things into water. 
In the winter, we see a lot with snow skiing, snowboarding, snowmobiling, and even just snowball fights. We offer a line of ski goggles and beanies as well as other winter accessories for enjoying cold activities, but all the while promoting that social aspect. 

We are also moving into the everyday, the urban explorer, finding things to do in the city. These are for people who enjoy going to sporing events, want to find the hole-in-the-wall restaurant that everyone is talking about. They enjoy going to concerts and taking in all that their city or town has to offer

Our second brand is Science of Skill. scienceofskill.com

Science of Skill promotes a knowledge base and library as well as supporting products for those who want to be able to survive through a variety of scenarios. We primarily focus on 3 key components: 

Outdoor - hiking, camping, fishing, hunting. These are the people who enjoy going out and roughing it. Some are weekend warriors, others are sharing the trip with family and/or friends. They are sleeping in tents, cooking their own food, have brought the right tools to survive for the weekend, because that is what they find fun. They have the right gear, but they are not traveling in an RV. 

Survival - expanding on the last category, these individuals are prepared at home as well. They want to have the right tools and knowledge to be able to protect themselves and their families in case of an intruder or a disaster. They are NOT, extreme preppers or thinking The Walking Dead is going to happen next year. 

They like having the best gear, they have every day carry items on them like a knife, a multi tool, an RFID protected wallet, a first aid kit in the car, etc. They are prepared, but not extreme. 

Tactical - building off the gear, these people want the best gear for everything from everyday carry items, to being prepared for anything. They value knowledge and preparedness in themselves, their families and their friends. Many are former or current military, law enforcement, first responders. 

Our demographics range from 35-65 years old, many are current or former military/ first responders. They pride themselves in having the best training, most up to date information, and best equipment. They also respect our history and heritage and want to pass that and their knowledge and skills on to the next generation. These individuals are family and community oriented.

We are a cybersecurity firm located in Columbia, MD. Anchor offers consulting services (assessments, monitoring, management, compliance) and is a reseller of security products locally and nationally. We also offer security training classes in our Columbia office.

Our target clients are a 800-2,000 seat environment. The average user is captured in our Buyer Persona below.

VIEWPOINT OF ARTICLES
The tone needs to be as if coming from a Sr. Business Advisor speaking to Fortune 1K company or its Sr. IT professional.

USING EXAMPLES
External links for content or relevant articles are always good to include with posts. We cannot name other cybersecurity companies or brands negatively (ex. a reported breach or vulnerability at FAMOUS security company b/c they have a loyal fan base we do not wish to alienate). Other companies’ examples are educational and instructive.

BUYER PERSONA PROFILE
Statistically male; runs the 20-person Information Technology group for the corporation/organization.
Is the lead IT person, the CIO/CISO or IT Director.
First IT job was as a software developer on an applications team, has had 5 previous jobs, increasing in responsibilities leading into management, so he knows the subject matter. Alternatively, he is an IT-savvy business leader with IT responsibility reporting to a company board.  Seeks respect from/answers to C-suite (CEO, COO, CFO and board). Typically, 40s-50s/Gen X.										

GOALS										
Seeks robust and stable technology solutions that fit his organization's mission.
Security, availability and appropriate business alignment.															

CHALLENGES										
IT budgets not keeping up with the complexity of technology and security requirements.
Lack of enough skilled workforce, spread thin. Sometimes a lack of skillset within current available workforce.
									
HOW WE HELP										
We provide cybersecurity strategy and risk solutions to ensure an organization, data and brand remains safe and secure. Can provide skilled IT staff for outsourcing IT needs. Virtual CIO/CISO services. 

Anchor is signed up with HubSpot and strives to follow their inbound methodology.

Xapnik provides tools to help small groups and networks stay together and engaged so they can reach their goals. Our first product is a social media tool that makes it easy for group members to keep track of and boost each other on social media and in blog comments.

We need several blog posts written for our launch.

We need standard-length (550-650 words) to long pieces (850-950 words) that fall into the following formats:
- lists (top 10 books, top 10 tech tools, 5 people to follow, etc.)
- how-to's (how to use gamification to keep your group engaged, etc.)
- advice/info (why supporting individuals in your group matters as much as the group's overall objectives, why personal networks will be even more important in the future, etc.)
- case studies of successful interest groups and personal networks 
- your suggestions here!

We're addressing under-served communities. We want to meet them where they are. They have limited resources and no material or societal advantages, so they don't want advice or stories that require or involve such advantages.

Stories and examples that reflect the people we're addressing are great. 
The problem we're solving for our user is the challenge of keeping a group or small network together and mutually beneficial after the initial rush of forming the group has worn off. 

We're blatantly socially liberal. We're loudly pro women, pro African American,  pro LGBTQ, pro Native American, pro equal rights for all communities who are currently under-served by the system.

Please check out http://blog.armstrongatknox.com/ for inspiration for these posts.

Our school has grown mostly thruogh word of mouth. We have excellent student satisfaction and great reviews on facebbok, TripAdvisor, youtube testimonials etc.  http://spanishandmore.com/reviews/

Hi,

We're a boutique estimating / drafting firm based in Brisbane, Australia but we work in all areas of Australia. Our main drive is that outsourcing this work is way more efficient and cost effective than hiring someone in house.

Thanks for your interest in contributing to MoneyPit.com!  Here's are a few tips we've put together just for BlogMutt writers:

We are home improvement and decor experts.  Readers of our publication come to us for trustworthy, entertaining, relatable information about remodeling, fixing, improving, decorating, organizing, cleaning, and shopping for supplies for their biggest investments — their homes! Our readers also look for gardening guidance, ecofriendly solutions, product recommendations, buying/selling information, and household hacks.

Please note: We will NOT purchase posts that offer inaccurate or amateurish advice or cite non-credible sources, or posts that contain info that is obviously "scraped" from other sites. We expect your post to be well researched, authoritative, friendly and ORIGINAL.

What Kinds of Content Does The Money Pit Publish?

We are open to publishing:
* Well-researched, service-driven articles (either evergreen or newsy/seasonal)
* Personal essays that teach a lesson or provide helpful information
* Step-by-step projects, especially those with accompanying photos
* Roundups of shorter tips

What Is the Tone/Voice of The Money Pit Content?
* MoneyPit.com publishes content with an authoritative yet accessible voice and tone. Our content is not preachy; it is confident. We pride ourselves on giving our content a “face,” so feel free to let your personal voice shine through. The more relatable your words sound, the better!
* Content should never sound condescending or judgmental.

Content for The Money Pit should:
* Be 100% original and not published anywhere else.
* Be well written, clear, interesting, and above all, helpful.
* Have a logical structure and flow.
* Use subheadings and bullets/lists, where appropriate, to make it easy for the reader to consume the information.
* Include a strong, compelling introduction and a conclusion that wraps up the article or provides a call to action.
* Attribute all data, quotes, and referenced content by hyperlinking to the original source.
* Be between 400 and 600 words; however, don’t sacrifice depth for brevity.
* Avoid overly promotional information. You can use a company as an an example, but it should be used as the basis for sharing knowledge. 

Style Tip: We often use a problem-solution formula when writing (or broadcasting). First talk we point out the “pain point” or problem, and we try to do so in a fun and relatable way.  Then, we present the solution.  For example, if we were writing about an oven cleaning tip, we might open with:

"You know that charred layer of crud representing all that’s left of your last 6 months of baking? Well it turns out that crud may he chock full something you’d not want to serve up in your next meal, bacteria!  Using a baking bag instead not only will put those memories of past pies and pot roast behind you, your oven will also be a lot safer for you and your family!"

Make sense?  Tell the reader about a problem in a fun and relatable way, and then solve it!


Finally...

* Links are encouraged.  Because home improvement can be very visual, including links in your story to examples of similar solutions, products, techniques or just for more information, can be very helpful for the reader.

* IMPORTANT: Please search MoneyPit.com to make sure we don’t already have a post similar (or identical!) to the one you’re writing, or for our Preferred Writers, before you pitch us a topic.  We respect your time and talent and don't like turning down otherwise well written posts because we have similar/identical content.  You can certainly refresh or build upon a story on the site, but please make sure it brings new value to the topic.  

And because WordPress has a notoriously poor search tool, you'll get a better, faster and more accurate search by using the Google "site:" command.  Just type "site:moneypit.com" followed by the term you are searching for and Google will return only content on moneypit.com for that search 

Thanks again for your interest and we can't wait to see your posts!

And some information on what makes us unique:
Mekanix Differentiators
1)	Semi-private class sizes.   Contrast with very large classes at many big box gyms, spin studios, some yoga studios, etc.

Because workouts consist of movements that can be easily adjusted to make them easier to harder, athletes can use their personalized program within normal classes to progress towards their goals.

About Mekanix

Calisthenics Differentiators
