Facing criminal charges means you need someone in your corner who understands how the system works. Attorney Kevin DeVore knows your rights and will fight to protect them. Kevin DeVore is a St. Paul Criminal Defense Lawyer.

Why I want to blog

1. To build our brand identity

I want Blackburn Coastal Realty to be positioned in the minds of:

•	Beach and beach-adjacent property owners as a real estate company that is focused on getting Top Dollar for its client properties by looking beyond the numbers to behavioral economics to bewitch buyers by making each property look like an HGTV showcase.
•	Local realtors as a real estate brokerage with only full-time professional realtors (not hobbyists) that truly know the market (particularly beach and waterfront), are not sloppy/do not half-ass it, whose listed properties are a pleasure to show, are pleasant to work with but not saps, can hold their own in negotiations without playing games, think outside the box with creative solutions to transaction snags, and always, always, always seem to be one step ahead with our content, listing marketing, and incorporation of technology in our business.
•	In the minds of Homebuyers as realtors with the inside story on properties and market trends, who fight for every penny on the buyer’s behalf.

...and can demonstrate it because of our original take on things, on the market, our focus on behavioral economics rather than numbers alone (home buyers buy with emotion/limbic system but justify their purchase using logic).  and can help them avoid costly errors (potential lawsuits). In other words, we make them more $ with higher sales prices while saving them $ that would have come out of their net proceeds. <<I don’t mean we discount our commission – we never discount our commission because even at full commission, we are underpaid for all we bring to the table - hiring me at full commission costs homeowners way less than hiring a discount broker.>>

When Realtors talk about their length of experience what they actually give is the # of years they’ve had a real estate license. What they don’t say is that the majority are hobbyists who do less than 1 transaction per year and have another primary income source (salaried full-time job, spousal income). So when an agent says “I’ve been in this business for 20 years” it means they have completed fewer than 20 transactions. I’ve worked full time as a realtor for 10 solid years. That means hundreds of transactions, thousands of valuable lessons that my clients benefit from. This is how I pay my bills. And real estate is a living, breathing thing. Markets fluctuate all the time, things change all the time, NAR and FAR and local RE boards change the documents all the time. If it’s been 12 months since you’ve done a transaction, there are customs that have changed (eg using the As Is instead of the regular contract) that leave unsuspecting homeowners vulnerable.
 
2. Real estate is an incredibly competitive field, and we need to make sure we stay ahead of the pack.

People prefer to do business with brands they know, and my blog is the perfect tool for letting people get to know me/us, get to know our brand. 64% of sellers who used a real estate agent found their agents through a referral by friends or family. Just someone they know. 

Because so many of the beach properties are 2nd homes and the owners live elsewhere, when it’s time to sell, they don’t ask a neighbor for a recommendation. They go online. I want to use blogging to become their digital Realtor-next-door, a trusted source. I want to stay top-of-mind so when they do sell, I’m the first person they think of.

We’ve lived in this part of Florida for 30+ years, but only lived at the beach for the last twelve years, so we don’t have the advantage of being the neighborhood Realtor who’s had 100s of yard signs over dozens of years. (note: with so many condos at the beach, most of the time we don’t get the opportunity to reinforce our brand with yard signs). An advantage we have over the entrenched Realtor-next-door types is that they are not tech savvy and some even resist technology. One guy, in particular, comes to mind. He refuses to text. We’re early adopters of tech. 

We’re educated (I have a Bachelor’s degree in Marketing & 2 home staging certs, Bill has his JD, we sharpen our knowledge and skills every single day), creative, specialists in understanding what buyers want. Also with out of town sellers, we take care of everything for them. We are their eyes and ears. If their house needs painting before listing, we find and supervise the painters. When a light bulb goes out, we change it. 

3. I want to create a personal connection with our blog’s readers.

I want our blogs to feel as if we are speaking directly to the reader and I want to blog about topics homeowners want to read about, such as___________. Speak directly to them, one-to-one, not from a detached perch.
I want to hit them in two stages of the home selling or buying process: research/info gathering and comparison/narrowing down which realtor to hire

4. Original content will make our business stand out and help us gain more trust than our competitors.

No one local is posting the type of content our audience wants to read. That audience is made up of people successful enough (usually in business, as entrepreneurs or high level corporate) to afford to spend $500,000 (usually cash) on a property they’ll use for a few weeks or months of the year. They’re educated, worldly, well-read, savvy consumers.

If our content gives readers information they want to see, they’ll associate our brand with that information. I want them to think there is no better place to learn about real estate and homeownership than us. And that we’re the best option for home selling advice.

To stand out, we have to say something different than other Realtors – to share valuable, one-of-a-kind information they won’t find anywhere else on the internet. Things that make them have “AHA” moments, like “I never thought of it that way” or “that makes perfect sense” or “I always wondered why that was and now I know”. Information that, even if it didn’t answer the exact question they had when they started searching the internet, did give them the valuable info they didn’t realize they needed and positioned us in their brains as a Realtor that probably has the answers for all their home selling questions. I want our blog to be so good that our prospective and past clients become ambassadors for our brand, by sharing our posts on social media. 

I do NOT want the type of fluffy, mindless, generic, poorly written or self-aggrandizing posts I see other Realtors running (I say running because I don’t think most other Realtors are actually writing their own content. I think they are using recycled or “borrowed” content or an inexpensive generic Realtor blog product). If we post the same articles as our competitors, then we’re not offering our audience value. And they’ll assume we’re no better than any other realtor.

Most agents are high school graduates, but a college education is rare, which might not show itself in conversation, but it definitely shows in their writing. The composition of emails I get from other agents? I know 10-year olds who write better! Substandard English, used by people who claim English as their only language – using the wrong words, poor grammar, screwed up syntax, is fingernails on a chalkboard for my target audience. And me.

5. I want to use our blog posts to generate organic traffic to our site and increase # of sign-ups for building our pipeline



ABOUT US:
Sellers love us because we understand what Buyers are looking for. We use that knowledge to help homeowners ready their properties for sale. Whether that means selecting a team for painting, clean-up, repairs, arranging for professional photographs or personally staging the interior & exterior to make the home look great & sell well...we do all the legwork, which is especially helpful for out-of-town owners. We treat each property like a product on a shelf & make it stand out next to the competition.

To get Top Dollar for our Sellers, we know we need to generate the maximum number of Buyer Showings. The more Qualified Buyers who see a property, the higher the likelihood of healthy offers. To that end, we use all of the current day Media to market your property...email campaigns, keyword-based websites, Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, YouTube, messaging, signs, direct mail, open houses and all of the available real estate portals like Realtor.com, ListingBook, Homes.com, Zillow & Trulia. We expose your property to millions of Buyers worldwide!

Properties sell quickly if priced correctly. In order to know where to set that price, we do extensive research prior to listing. Part of determining the correct price for your home involves taking a look at similar homes that have sold recently and doing a Comparable Market Analysis (CMA). That's as far as most Realtors go, but in today's rapidly changing marketplace, it is also important to consider the current market conditions. What else is available for sale right now? Those are the properties Buyers will compare yours to and we use that information to create a pricing & positioning strategy. Selling property is all about positioning. Your house doesn't have to be THE BEST HOUSE EVER. It just has to appear equal to or better than the alternatives.

We don't just LIST properties -- we SELL them!

For Buyers, the first thing we do is Listen. We listen to what Buyers say (and don't say) about their preferences and must-haves. With this information, we pinpoint homes that meet those criteria, then continue to refine our searches based on Buyers' reactions to homes we show them. We are in daily contact with our Buyers -- immediately notifying them of new listings or price changes and educating them about things they will encounter in the home buying process (i.e., inspection, appraisal). Buyers moving from out-of-state love us because we know the area so well and because we use videos and FaceTime to keep those Buyers in the loop during every stage of the home buying process.

Homes that are well maintained and reasonably priced go under contract very quickly. That's why it's important to work with a Realtor who works full time in the business. Most agents are part-time, which limits their availability for anything from showings to answering questions and their power to help Buyers react quickly when bargain properties hit the market.

Once we find the perfect home, we guide Buyers through the negotiation process, contract paperwork, home inspection, financing, appraisal, final walk-thru & closing. Our agents are available via text, email, fax, or phone call so that they can take action on any issues or questions along the way.

How many times have you watched a keynote, listened to a podcast, or read a business book where the concepts were resonating with you. Then, you turn the page and they tell you how Disney, Starbuck, Apple, or SAP used these techniques to grow. For 99% of the business out there, these processes don't apply. Companies with small marketing teams and realistic budget need special systems to grow. The business media lies to us by showing off how companies with huge budgets and tons of name recognition grow - because well-known names are sexy.

I grew my last company using 100% inbound leads from marketing. I was a team of one for a long time and we were not a funded company. That meant that i needed to figure this out on my own and use low-cost tools and processes to grow, or else I would not have a job. Ultimately, we grew from 10 leads/month to 300 leads/month. 

After we sold that company, I wanted to give back to the marketing community. I had developed specialized processes and system for growing companies without a big marketing team or big marketing budget. So, I developed programs to teach other marketers how to do what I did. Training people how to grow their company without a big marketing budget or big marketing teams (and providing supporting services) is what Small Marketing Teams is all about.

Lastly, the bar is really high for me when it comes to marketing advice. It these blogs seems basic or fluffy, I can't use them. I need my audience to know that I understand them better than they understand their marketing strategy. I don't want to talk down to people. I want to be helpful. I need to talk about things that get actual results.  I like three-part story formats for posts (status quo, the problem with the status quo, resolution).

Why do I do this:
I do it for the newly hired marketing director who soon released that the company is relying almost entirely on her magic to grow.
I do this for the law firm that is committed to doing right by their clients and community, but needs more retainers to continue down this path.
I do this for the entrepreneur that  had a good run with word of mouth referrals until something changed in their market and the easy leads dried up.
I do this for the executive that has a new approach that will improve the lives of their prospective customers if they only gave them the chance.
I do this for the business owners that have piece-mealed every shiny marketing object over the past 5 years and are finally frustrated and running out of steam.
I do this for the parters that see companies who were once peers leapfrogging them in their industry.
I do this for the CMO who believes in their company and products, but doesn't have a repeatable process for bring in qualified leads.
My goal is  to use the blog post for building personal brand such as LinkedIn in the field that i'm working in. Linkedin Publishing or the like

Client offers payment solutions and value-added services to courts. Benefits (including convenience) of these services applies to both court clerks/administrators and citizens. And when citizens have more options, they are more likely to pay their fines — as often as needed and on time which increases revenue for the courts and is positive for citizens. 

They also offer custom integrations in which their payment solutions integrate with court management systems (CMS). Key benefits include: helps ensure accurate data and avoids manual processing using various systems.

Court side: Courts can be slow to embrace new technology, so it’s important to highlight the importance of new options/features without saying court clerks need to implement it do their jobs better. Must come across lighter and more-so as beneficial to them as well. Their time and efforts are valuable, and client offerings support this notion. 

Citizen side: Client supports “Justice For All.” This means citizens should have the resources needed to be able to pay with ease and on time. Offering citizens more options than paying on-premises such as online or over the phone causes less workarounds for them. For example, if transportation is an issue — rather than trying to find a ride to the courthouse, potentially affecting work as well, they can simply use an off-premises option.

Justice For All link: http://www.azcourts.gov/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=bmEC0PU-FD8%3D&portalid=74

JMB is unique because we handle both workers’ compensation and personal injury cases. Here's a summary of stem cell topics related to website offering over time:
Bone-marrow stem cells - the Holy Grail of Healing - have unique ability to self-replicate throughout the entire life of an organism and to differentiate into cells for organs, tissue, bone...whole body. 

This means your heart, leg muscles, back ligaments and muscle, brain cells, your bone structure, etc. Your body was/is a stem cell producing machine...at least up until age 12 or so, then, like some things, production and proliferation drop, along with one's youth-like ability to heal, mend, and recover almost as quickly as the injury/illness. 

The human body has a mechanism to naturally release stem cells from the bone marrow to send stem cells to various areas of the body for regeneration and repair – we found this can be enhanced nutritionally to phenomenal levels. When there is an injury, tear, collapse, or injured tissue, stem cells are released to support the phenomenon of regeneration and repair in the body. 

(I think there’s a logo here somewhere…very simple – “I’m a bone-marrow stem cell” watch what happens when I repair you…this is what Ponce’ De leon was looking for…).

I want to intersperse (for freshness & longevity of discussions, permutations, etc...) stem cell topics with other health/longevity/rehabilitation/chronic illness related posts/articles to take a position as an expert on stem cell nutrition as the Holy Grail of healing...the touchstone, so to speak.

Digify is a document security service that enables businesses a way to track and protect information online. 

Entrepreneurs and professionals use Digify to send sensitive documents that usually contain intellectual property information and should be kept private and confidential. About Calvary Hospital
Calvary is the country’s only hospital dedicated to providing hospice and palliative care to adult patients with advanced cancer and other life-limiting illness. CalvaryCareSM is available at four locations in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens and throughout the greater New York area where people reside.

Calvary’s mission today is the same as when we started nearly 120 years ago. Our family-centric approach to patient care is key to relieving the stress and concerns of family members as well.
Calvary Hospital is the only fully accredited acute care specialty hospital in the U.S. exclusively providing palliative care for adult patients with advanced cancer and other life-limiting illnesses. Our programs include inpatient care, pain management, hospice, home care with bereavement and support programs for families and friends.

Calvary’s mission is to care for medical, emotional and spiritual needs of our patients and their families, at the end of their lives. We believe that the no person should have to be in pain or be uncomfortable at this time.

We are the world’s leading expert in palliative care. CalvaryCareSM is compassionate, loving care that we provide to our patients, wherever we care for them.

Patients & Families
We want you and your loved ones to feel taken care of. Learn more about preparing for a hospital stay, billing and financial services, and support programs.

We are committed to making your time at Calvary as comfortable and worry-free as possible. The information in this section will provide you with all the necessary details for your, your loved ones, and your family.

End-stage illness often leads to problems that are difficult to handle. Calvary Hospital’s family-centric approach to patient care has been instrumental to our success in helping relieve the pain and suffering of thousands of patients and families.

Social Work/Family Care Practitioners are available to help patients and their families in coping with the stresses that accompany illness and hospitalization. Additionally, our Family Care Center offers an area of respite for all visitors where a variety of complimentary services are offered to assist in maintaining wellness and decreasing stress.

Support Groups
Relatives and friends of Calvary Hospital patients are invited to attend these weekly groups. Professionally led by a Social Work/Family Care Practitioner, the groups are designed as a special opportunity to talk about your own experience as a family member or friend of a patient.

Information About Wine-Oh! (in no particular order)

Overview - Wine-Oh! is a free mobile app that recommends wine you'll love and provides discounts for you to try them. Our technology uses Artificial Intelligence (specifically machine learning) to predict new wines you'll like based on the aromas and tastes you detect in wines you like. When you rate a wine we'll provide you with the flavors that other members have detected in that wine. Members then choose which flavors they detected to create their own unique tasting profile for a given wine. We use that pattern to connect you to the virtual wine cellars of other users that shared the same tasting profile for the wine. The goal being that you'll probably like other wines from they like because you share the same taste in a wine you both liked. We rank those wines and place the best ones on your Recommendations List.

Business Model - On the back end we've built a system for wine producers and retailers to create discounts in the form of rebates for members to try their wines. Accordingly Wine-Oh! will recommend wines you'll love and the Wine Producer of that wine  and your local retailer might give you a discount to buy it. Members then buy the wine at any retailer and snap a photo of the receipt to prove they bought the wine. The discount amount is transferred to the Members account and they can transfer their balance to their bank account. As such, we only make money when (a) a member receives a rebate discount and (b) when the member purchases the wine. We do not sell or ship wine. 

Rebates vs. Coupons - an important distinction of our service is the difference between rebates and coupons. When you receive a discount at the time of purchase (which lowers how much you pay) that is a coupon. When you receive the discount after you pay, that is a rebate. Rebates one Wine are allowed in every state but one; whereas Coupons on Wine are not allowed in many states.

Value Propositions
Consumer - get wine recommendations and discounts to buy them.
Wine Producer - discover new customers that are predicted to love your wines and increase sales by offering them discounts to buy your wine.
Retailer/Distributor - drive buyers into your store by offering discounts to local members to make your store the best price for wines on their recommendations.

Market Threats - For retailers, online wine sales and Amazon are eating into their wine sales. Although neither is a formidable threat today, as Millennials are becoming the dominant cohort in the wine market these alternative channels will become more prevalent. Amazon is opening distribution centers across the country and their purchase of Whole Foods means that they have many more shelves to deliver from and licenses to sell liquor in many of the hottest wine markets. Wine-Oh! enables retailers to connect with wine buyers and drive them into their stores (where they''ll also put other items into their cart). For Wine Producers, the two tier system of distributors and retailers being between them and the customer means that they don't have any connection to the consumers who purchase and drink their wine. Some consumers will goto their website, join their wine club or sign up for their mailing list. But most of their consumers are unknown to them. Accordingly they can't directly influence sales. However, with Wine-Oh!, they can not only connect with their consumers but also discover new consumers that are likely to enjoy their wines and become loyal customers. 

Intent - We are a pre-launch company desiring to start building up wine related content on our site. 

Customer Acquisition Model - With limited discounts available (e.g. not infinite on every wine), discounts are allocated to Members on a sliding scale with the top members getting discounts first and then down through the ranks to new users. As such we provide members with the ability to improve their status on Wine-Oh!. Some of these include logging usage (e.g. drinking, buying, rating) and inviting others to join Wine-Oh! and follow you (e.g. when you rate a wine it is shared with your following and they might add the wine to their collection to try). Thus we encourage our users to both use Wine-Oh! and invite others to use it too. The payoff being enhancements to one's status and receiving more wine discounts.

Blog Categories - All of our blog posts will go into one of three primary categories in our Community Discussion Section (https://goo.gl/jNkjgU): News, The Lounge or Tips & Tricks. Posts in these sections also show up on the main website (e.g. the News section of the website is a feed of the News Posts from the Community). When submitting an article we would like you to indicate which section you believe it should be placed.

Competition - we don't consider other wine apps competition per se; the closest would be Wine Ring. Others like Vivino, Wine Cellar, Hello Vino and Wine-Searcher have features that overlap with some of ours. We don't mind linking to them but it should be for a very topical reason rather than a casual link (e.g. if it makes the story relevant go ahead and link to them both otherwise avoid wine apps).

We want to help the world get a better night's sleep by dismissing the myths, cutting through the misconceptions, and getting down to the core of what you need to achieve great sleep and how it impacts everything you do.

We want to keep our blog light and airy but substantial. Meaning we do not want to engage in heavy topics but we do want our content to be informative and leave the reader with the sense that they learned something or are better off for having read our post.

Overall voice and tone
Playful, but expert
Intelligent
Helpful and informational
Not corporate
Conversational and funny

With this tone it's easy to get (but we DON'T want to be):

Cheesy-funny is one thing, but smart/subtle funny (not lame funny). Examples of cheesy are: Words like Hangry and Yolo, Throwback Thursday, Cat memes, etc...

Average-We are unique people with a unique brand and a unique product. Our words should reflect our uniqueness and we don't do what everyone else does. Examples of average are: (see Cheesy)
 
Unprofessional-We want funny and playful, but with a clear throughline of intelligent expertise and professionalism

Topics to absolutely stay away from: 
Politics and Trump specifically (we take no stance)
Religion (we take no stance)
Heavy news stories (you know...death, destruction, plague-stay away from spreading that vibe)
Our competition (we focus on us, not them)

Our Philosophy:
Epica will inspire and delight its customers with high-quality, elegant, Italian handcrafted products that inspire creativity among its users. Epica will strive to maintain a strong connection to its Italian heritage while also offering a modern/convenient online experience via the world's very highest quality journals and albums. Epica strives to elicit a truly personal experience through its hand-crafted products and personalization for a lasting impression.

Visual Tone and Voice: 
The Epica brand represents quality, Italian craftsmanship, elegance and creative inspiration.  These are the voices that should be conveyed throughout all visual and textual communications.  Whether on our website, social media, specific Ad campaigns or through the presentation of the product itself, the online shopping experience should represent these thematic elements throughout.One of the most unique and important themes to convey through visual and text communications is Epica’s Italian heritage.  Transport our audience to Italy –Florence, which more specifically lies in the heart of Tuscany, is the home of quality bookmaking, hand-cut paper and leather artisans. Florence is known the world over for its quality leather and paper products.  The symbol for the city of Florence is the fleur de lis, which is why Epica uses it as part of its brand image. Florence is also known as the center for the Italian Renaissance, it’s intimately connected with the birth of creative inspiration and expression.Epica products have a visually aesthetic character that is enhanced tactilely- through both touch and smell. Obviously, this is limited by e-commerce, which puts an added burden on marketing to convey the tactile experience visually.  Keep this in mind as you endeavor to express Epica’s unique benefits.

Our business proposition is simple and can be told in multiple forms. Today's media landscape has become too cluttered. In order to be competitive, we believe businesses should employ Strategic Partnerships and have a Regatta BrandAgent on their team to properly represent their brand in the marketplace of potential partners. Rather that always spending money on expensive media and marketing programs, there are almost always opportunities to “look inward” and leverage – even monetize – existing brand marketing and media assets. Doing this properly requires the expertise, perseverance and bandwidth that only a Regatta BrandAgent can offer. 1) All articles need to include screenshots of the processes being explained. Please aim to include at least 5 screenshots per article.

2) Do not link to any WordPress or Jetpack competitors (Squarespace, Wix, Web.com, Drupal, Joomla, Tumblr, Weebly, Medium, WPBeginner posts, and any other unofficial WordPress websites,  links to or mentions of any direct Jetpack competitors, including but not limited to: Google AdWords, Yoast SEO, WordFence, Clutch, Carbonite, etc.)

3) If you are linking to a report or citing a statistic, please cite the original source of data. For example, do not cite The New York Times if the original data was compiled by an analyst firm. Additionally, links should be no older than 2 years (2016 at the latest).

4) These articles should not focus on explaining how to complete a process with Jetpack. Every article should focus on providing insights into why a user will benefit from the Jetpack features in question. We want readers to learn about new tools and features that can enhance their sites and how they can benefit in ways they were previously unaware of. You may include a few brief sentences about how to activate a tool or feature, but it shouldn't read as a document over a friendly blog post. One way to avoid this is by incorporating as many examples as possible. These can be real ones, or made up ones. Examples help readers visualize how they could potentially use the features being described in the articles to their own advantages. When in doubt - use an example! 

5) Every article should begin with an opener that reveals what will be discussed within. Some great past examples include:

"In this post, we’ll cover why you need to perform regular backups, why they should be made offsite, and offer a solution so that you won’t have to worry about losing your data in the event of a mistake or emergency."

"Want to learn how to grow your social presence with Jetpack? Keep reading!"

"Read on to learn some tips that will help you build stronger relationships with even stronger contact forms."

6) Every article should end in a conclusion that includes its own subheading that wraps up the entire piece. There should also be a strong call-to-action at the very end. Some great examples of CTA's include:

"What tips do you have to get more contact forms filled out? Let us know in the comments below, we’d love to hear from you!"

"What tips do you have to keep your site safer? We’d love to hear from you in the comments below"

"Can you think of any other tips or tricks to offer the food blogger community? Share them with us in the comments section below."

7) Subheadings are strongly encouraged, but they should never be formatted as questions. For example:

"How can Jetpack help you do this?" 

This is not an appropriate subheading for this program. We want to answer this question in the subhead to explain exactly what the section entails. 

8) Avoid using words like "simple" and "easy" as we do not want to imply that these processes are simple if some readers are having trouble understanding them. We don't want to make them feel bad.

From our About Us page......

Philosophy
Chubo was created with the goal of sharing the immense and unparalleled talent of Japanese blacksmiths with chefs and culinary enthusiasts around the world.

Despite the growing awareness and popularity of Japanese kitchen knives around the world, the number of people hand-forging blades, hand finishing edges and crafting handles decreases every year.

We hoped through our business, we could contribute in a small way to preserving an ancient craft and vital source of tools for the culinary world.

Product Lines
When we first started the company, we traveled around Japan meeting blacksmiths and searching out makers who were using traditional forging methods. The Japanese blacksmith world is quite a small and intimate one, so as the company’s grown we’ve also been introduced to other blacksmiths in different regions in Japan. We continue to add to our product lines based on these growing relationships as well as from suggestions we receive from our customers in the culinary industry.

In addition to Japanese kitchen knives we also offer sharpening tools, knife accessories, small kitchenwares, Japanese barware and cocktail supplies and products for Japanese coffee service.

Industry Prices for Everyone, with less overhead than traditional retail we are able to offer high quality products without the margins found in most kitchen stores.

Knife Services
Every Chef knows, your knives are only as good as the blades you are able to maintain. We offer expert sharpening and repair as well as tools and resources to learn to care for your Japanese chef knives. Visit our blog for sharpening techniques and tips and shop our collection of highest quality natural and synthetic sharpening stones.

Customers
It is our honor to supply Japanese chef knives, kitchen tools and tableware for some of the finest chefs and restaurants in the world. You will find our products in use at Daniel, Cosme, Le Coucou, Contra, The Grill, Rose’s Luxury, Pineapple & Pearls, Fork, Spoon & Stable, Rustic Canyon, State Bird Provisions, Quince Restaurant, Senia, Pujol, Dersou, Dinner by Heston Blumenthal, Atoboy, Tetsuya’s and Momofuku Seibo to name a few.

Location
Our online store is our primary retail location. We have offices in Tokyo and New York, and our team travels regularly in North America, Oceania, and Europe. If you would like to put your kitchen on our radar for future sales visits please get in touch. Online orders ship from our Japan Warehouse.

Keep your people happy, through recognition and reward.

At Wogi, your employees’ and customers’ satisfaction and retention come first. 

Whether you run an eCommerce business or a brick-and-mortar store, recognising and rewarding your loyal customers and employees has proven to have a great positive impact on business results. Our business-to-business model is designed to provide a range of digital gifts for employee recognition, customer loyalty programs, campaign reward systems and sales incentive programs.


Spark the brightest possibilities with digital rewards. 

At Wogi, we unlock possibilities by providing rewarding solutions on-demand with our state-of-the-art technology platform that allows you to get creative and choose the best digital gifts that truly meet your customers or staff needs and preferences.

Wogi has been revolutionizing the gift industry in Asia by eliminating operational costs through digitalizing the entire process; from procurement, inventory management to delivery. Implementing a rewards campaign has never been quicker, and now comes without the hassle of physical printing and delivery requirements. Most importantly, Wogi enables you to meaningfully reward your people, instantly.

Natural Waters is an entire home water filtration system company providing clean water for family homes across Southern California.

Automattic is the company behind WordPress.com, WooCommerce, Jetpack, Simplenote, Longreads, VaultPress, Akismet, Gravatar, Polldaddy, Cloudup, and more. They believe in "making the web a better place."

A distributed company with 538 Automatticians in 52 countries speaking 75 different languages, their common goal is to democratize publishing so that anyone with a story can tell it—regardless of income, gender, politics, language, or where they live in the world.

Take a moment to explore the WordPress.com site in order to get a sense of the kinds of users we're speaking to. Visit The Daily Post to get a feel for the Automattic/WordPress.com brand voice, or visit The WordPress.com Blog for additional WordPress.com-related information.

WordPress.com vs. WordPress.org
While they share many things in common, .org and .com are two different entities. This content program is for WordPress.com, so content should be focused around that ecosystem. See here for more information on what makes them different.

Program Objectives
The Automattic content marketing site is a place where business-minded creators and do-ers can find the information they need to kick-start their businesses online. It's a place where they can find the key advice they need to achieve their online goals—today and tomorrow.

We offer a new, pragmatic perspective on launching a website. Doing so doesn't have to be daunting—not in today's business world. We empower independent makers and do-ers to achieve their goals for standing up and evolving their web presence.

Mission Statement
If you're a business owner or creator striving to better communicate with and serve your audience, you've probably already asked yourself: "Do I need a website?" For those that aren't already online, that's a tough question to tackle. After all, many independent business owners and creators don't really know what goes into standing up a website, or how they can benefit from one.

With our content, we will provide the knowledge, insights, and information today's business owners and creators need to bring their passion online—one (small) step at a time.

What to do and not to do:-
- No camelCasing please
- Please no use of the words pooches and pussy or pussy cats It's not that we don't love cats and dogs :-) but for obvious reasons. 
- Refer to animals as animals or pets rather than creatures unless referring to others works
- Our customers are students rather than clients or customers. 
- Use Work placement or Workplace practical training rather than work experience when referring to students who are studying with us and are undertaking the practical component of the course. We use the term work experience for students who  might want to improve their eligibility for our course. e.g. We recommend applicants gain work experience in the animal care industry prior to submitting an application.  
- On-campus rather than on campus
- Full-time rather than fulltime
- We don't tend to use the 'z' in Australia as much as the 's' - hard to get used to but it is empathise rather than empathize, specialise rather than specialize.

There are a few common veterinary words which are spelled slightly differently in Australia. The spelling we use:-
- Anaesthetic  
- Behaviour
